content:
This guy is copying your puzzle as his clash:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5130075d5f435855169287e412312a5503fb8

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A nice simple puzzle that will encourage those starting out.  String handling is always good : )

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it is a VERY easy puzzle but you did a real job to carry out the tests it's very beautiful !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Lots of love went into this one.

I suppose the WIP part here is the validators as they are essentially the same as the test cases except with the word "Validator" before and after the ASCII art. Would like to see that changed before approval.

Besides that, pretty nice puzzle. It's easy to understand what to do and the test cases are well designed.

Suggestions:
- Format the statement better.
----- Samples of [[recipe]] and their outputs should be written as constants instead of enclosing them in quotation marks.
----- Same goes for the abbreviations; they should be written as constants instead of in boldface.
- Change the constraint of [[recipe]]: The shortest valid length of [[recipe]] is 5 (1# nl).

In 'A foundation of 8's' how am I supposed to read the chunk '168' ? 
I mean I know that it's supposed to be sixteen eights but why not 1 times 68... 

Sure you say:
"25" means "55"
"103" means "3333333333"
but what to do with "1036" (I know this never happens). Should I print 10 times 36, 103 times 6 etc.? 

In other words, from where to where am I supposed to cut these types of chunks, explicitly ? For example, is the char always 1 digit max ?

Thank you for the feedback.
Yes, I'm glad you noticed that.

I spent a lot of time trying to figure out the absolute shortest way to do notation in the "recipe".
At one point I had a symbol like 
10=3
to indicate to type "3" 10 times but then that caused a problem decoding an image when actual "=" symbols were in the image itself.

Eventually I realized you don't need that because yes by definition, a character is 1 character (not sure the technical way to say that).
So if a chunk is only digits (such as 25 or 103), you know that the last character is the character and all the ones to the left are "how many".
In other words, if a chunk is only digits then the pattern is xy or xxy or xxxy or xxxxy etc where y is character and x is the "how many"

To address your specific example:
The recipe to print "36" 10 times (aka to print "36363636363636363636")
is
13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16 13 16

I kind of like that this "complication" is part of it.  In my opinion, that makes it qualify more as a "Classic Puzzle" than a "Clash"

Thank you for all the feedback.

The phrasing from https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/test-cases states "Each validator must differ from the corresponding test. It's only to ensure that the players don't hardcode the solution" and I think my validators do that.  No?

But I have actually written my own private program to translate images into recipes, so doing 4 more won't be hard, and so I will probably go ahead and do that. :)

UPDATE : Done :)
UPDATE: I added a bunch more tests/validators
Thank you so much for the Approval and the kind words :)
Thank you so much.  I appreciate it !!!

Yikes !!
Why would someone do that??!!??
Yes, that's really bad, especially so in your case because you've always put a lot of effort into creating your contributions.

So much fun to see those ASCII art come out too.  It will be very encouraging for novice coders and I can see this creating a lot of smiles.

We may have to change your name to :

"Lisa-Has-Great-Ideas"

; )
Thank you so much.  It makes me ridiculously happy to see people using this and especially now giving me such good ratings (4.7 as of now!!)

I believe I have made all the other changes you suggested.  Let me know if not.  

Thanks again for the feedback :)  -- great suggestions

Sure, don't get me wrong I like it too, I just wished there was a note somewhere that said 'if the chunk is composed only by numbers, the character is the last digit'.
But then again, maybe you are right and such a note would be redundant.
Thanks for the feedback; I'll think about it :)

I think you are right.  I added your suggested phrase.

And I added a new line underneath the castle that contains several "68" chunks to thoroughly test the code.

(I welcome any additional feedback)
